org.jtrim.image.transform

Enum InterpolationType

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<InterpolationType>
      • org.jtrim.image.transform.InterpolationType
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<InterpolationType>

    public enum InterpolationType
extends java.lang.Enum<InterpolationType>
    Defines types of interpolation to be used when scaling an image. In many cases, implementations will use the requested interpolation type. However, this is not required, when an implementation does not support the requested interpolation type, it may choose another one (which is supported).

    Warning: New interpolation types can be added at any time.

    See Also:
    AffineImageTransformer, SimpleAsyncImageDisplay

    • Enum Constant Summary

      Enum Constants 
      Enum Constant and Description
      BICUBIC
      Defines that the bicubic interpolation is to be used.
      BILINEAR
      Defines that the bilinear interpolation is to be used.
      NEAREST_NEIGHBOR
      Defines that the nearest-neighbor interpolation is to be used.

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • NEAREST_NEIGHBOR

        public static final InterpolationType NEAREST_NEIGHBOR
        Defines that the nearest-neighbor interpolation is to be used. This is the most basic kind of interpolation which simply chooses the closest pixel when resampling an image.

        Usually this interpolation type is the most efficient in terms of speed. All implementations should support nearest-neighbor interpolation.

      • BILINEAR

        public static final InterpolationType BILINEAR
        Defines that the bilinear interpolation is to be used. This interpolation calculates the pixel value from the 4 surrounding pixels. In most cases this results in a far better quality image than image interpolated using the nearest-neighbor interpolation.

        In most cases this interpolation type is a good trade-off between speed and quality.

      • BICUBIC

        public static final InterpolationType BICUBIC
        Defines that the bicubic interpolation is to be used. This interpolation calculates the pixel value from the 16 surrounding pixels. This requires considerably more computing power than bilinear interpolation but usually produces a more smooth image.
